Extract Direction of Arrival (DOA) Solutions Using MUSIC Algorithm

Source: R/SeaSondeRCS_MUSIC.R
seasonder_MUSICExtractDOASolutions.Rd

This function analyzes projection data using the Multiple Signal Classification (MUSIC) algorithm to identify Direction of Arrival (DOA) solutions for radar signals. It implements the methodology described by Paolo and Terril (2007) for HF radar signal analysis.

Usage

seasonder_MUSICExtractDOASolutions(projections)

Arguments

projections

A matrix of projections where each column corresponds to a set of MUSIC spectra for single and dual solutions. The matrix should have the attribute "bearings" indicating the corresponding bearing angles in degrees.

Value

A list containing the extracted single and dual DOA solutions, each with:

  • bearing: The bearing(s) corresponding to the detected peak(s).

  • a: The associated antenna pattern matrix values for the detected peak(s).

  • peak_resp: The response levels at the detected peak(s) in dB.

Details

The function performs the following steps:

  1. Reverses the distances for single and dual solution projections to enhance peak detectability.

  2. Detects peaks in the reversed single solution projection, retaining the highest peak.

  3. Detects peaks in the reversed dual solution projection, retaining the two highest peaks.

  4. Maps the identified peak positions back to their corresponding bearings.

The identification of DOA solutions using MUSIC relies on the inversion of spectral distances, as detailed in Paolo and Terril (2007), to emphasize potential peaks corresponding to source directions.

References

Paolo, S., & Terril, E. (2007). Detection and characterization of signals in HF radar cross-spectra using the MUSIC algorithm. Journal of Atmospheric and Oceanic Technology.

See also

seasonder_MUSICExtractPeaks, pracma::findpeaks

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
projections <- matrix(runif(100), nrow = 2, ncol = 50)
attr(projections, "bearings") <- seq(0, 359, length.out = 50)
result <- seasonder_MUSICExtractDOASolutions(projections)
print(result)
} # }
